Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Assembling the Immunoglobulin Loci Across Mammalian Species and Across the Human Population

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic raised the challenge of developing new computational techniques for understanding the immune response to emerging pathogens. This project will develop a new computer program for analyzing the parts of the genome that are responsible for immune responses to pathogens. This will enable analyses of the development of immunity to the virus in human populations by characterizing the mutations that are essential to the immune response. This research will also enhance understanding of the immune responses in bats, which are hosts to large numbers of coronaviruses, and in llamas, which are potentially an important source for a robust vaccine against the virus. The project will also develop a Massive Online Open Course “Bioinformatics of SARS-COV-2” that will cover various aspects of computational analysis of emerging pathogens, and the challenges of analyzing these complex and dynamic parts of the human genome. <br/><br/>Information about the immunoglobulin-encoding regions in the genome is critically important for analyzing the immune response to the novel SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus, developing antibody drugs against SARS-COV-2, and testing future vaccines against SARS-CoV-2. However, there are still no algorithms for inferring the sequences of the highly complex and rapidly evolving immunoglobulin (IG) loci. Moreover, although the immunoglobulin genes within the IG loci form the building blocks of antibodies, there are still no software tools for accurate identification of these genes. This project will develop a new algorithm for assembling and annotating the IG loci. These methods will be applied to multiple mammalian genomes with a focus on assembling the unusually complex IG loci in bats to characterize their immune response to coronaviruses. A second focus will be assembly of camelid IG loci to aid in developing vaccines against SARS-COV-2, taking advantage of the simpler and more stable antibodies present in this group. The project will also focus on assembling the highly variable immunoglobulin loci in multiple COVID-19 patients with the goal of revealing functionally important mutations in these loci. The project entails substantial risk, because the IG loci have been recalcitrant to all previous assembly attempts, but enhanced understanding of mammalian immunoglobin genes would greatly enhance the ability of society to predict and respond to current and future pandemics.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID-19 pandemic raised the challenge of developing novel computational techniques for understanding the origin of emerging zoonotic viruses and preventing their transmission to humans. Information about the immunoglobulin (IG) loci is critically important for the ongoing efforts to analyze host immune response to SARS-COV-2. Assembling the IG loci across multiple mammalian species and across human population is important for analyzing immune response in viral hosts, engineering antibody drugs against SARS-COV-2, and testing future vaccines.

 

Since the human IG locus is one of the most variable regions in the human genome, identifying variations in this locus is important since they have been linked to differential response to infection and vaccination. Population-wide IG sequencing is important for analyzing a highly variable response to COVID-19 across patients since mutations in the IG locus are known to be associated with poor response to vaccines. It is thus important to search for associations between failures of the future vaccines and variations in the IG loci. Thus, population-wide sequencing of the IG loci is important for future vaccine testing efforts. However, the IG loci proved to be extremely difficult to assemble.

 

 

The IG assembly challenge extends to large-scale genomics projects, such as the Vertebrate Genomes Project. On the other hand, the Human Pangenome Project, aimed at a difficult challenge of population-scale sequencing of complete human genomes, promises to revolutionize population genomics and personalized medicine.

 

Even in a high-quality assembly, the IG loci are often broken in multiple contigs - the lack of accurate assemblies prevents comparative genomics studies of adaptive immunity across various species. Difficulties in the IG assembly prevent further immunogenomics studies in bats and other potential career of zoonotic viruses.  

 

Another unsolved problem is annotating the IG loci, a prerequisite for follow-up immunogenomics studies. Remarkably, before this project started, there were no specialized software for annotating IG genes even in the case of the well-assembled IG loci.

 

Solving the challenge of the IG assembly and annotation will enable both the comparative genomics approach (across multiple vertebrates) and personalized immunogenomics approach (across multiple humans). We have achieved two interconnected goals: developing a new long-read assembler (LJA) that successfully assembles mammalian IG loci and developing a new Ig annotation tool (IgDetective). We are now collaborating with the Vertebrate Genome Project (VGP) consortium to annotate the immunoglobulin genes across all genomes assembled by VGP. This goal would be unattainable without developing IGDetective.
